result.title: Editorial of AoPS April Fools 2015
result.content:
[Problem A: Andrew and Interesting Game]

Here, Andrew is playing in a game versus the computer. He is allowed n guesses to guess a d-digit number. Each line represents one of Andrew's guesses. If he guesses a number that doesn't have d digits, he gets 42 as a response. Otherwise, he gets a number with zeros and ones, saying which digits he guessed were correct. If, by the end, he knows the number exactly, output the number, else output 42.

[Problem B: Andrew and 108]

Ok, I didn't provide nearly enough sample data for this problem so I had to make another announcement. The answer was: let k be the product of the distinct primes in the factorization of n (the inputted number), and output n / k for k times.

[Problem C: (Something close to) Anagram of 2015 AMC 10A Problem 14]

Clocks. Trace 10 -> 2 -> 6 on a clock and you get the number 7. Trace the remaining sequences and you get 48165.
